resources.string: Maps have suggested ability descriptors. Shenandoah\'s Hiking Difficulty is determined by a numerical rating using the following formula:

Elevation Gain x 2 x distance (in miles). The product's square root is the numerical rating. For example, a 10-mile hike that gains 2,200 feet in elevation:
 2,200 x 2=4,400
 4,400 x 10 = 44,000
 Square root of 44,000=209.8

The hike\'s numerical rating is then tied to one of five descriptors: Easiest, Moderate, Moderately Strenuous, Strenuous, Very Strenuous. \nThe example hike (above) would be rated Very Strenuous. \nThere are a few exceptions to the formula\'s validity, such as Dark Hollow Falls. Although its numeric rating of 36.3 puts it in the \"Easiest\" range, its steepness over such a short distance warrants a \"Moderate.\"
Numerical Rating: less than 50\n A hike that is generally suitable for anyone who enjoys walking. Mostly level or with a slight incline. Generally less than 3 miles.

Numerical Rating: 50-100\n A moderate hike is generally suitable for novice hikers who want a bit of a challenge. The terrain will involve a moderate incline and may have some steeper sections. Generally 3 to 5 miles.
Numerical Rating: 100â€“150\n Moderately Strenuous hikes will generally be challenging for an unconditioned person. The terrain will involve a steady and often steep incline. Generally 5 to 8 miles.

Numerical Rating: 150-200\n Strenuous hikes will challenge most hikers. The hike will generally be longer and steeper, but may be deemed "Strenuous" because of the elevation gain. Generally 7 to 10 miles.
